body: As of June 2017, Apache SIS source code is still hosted on Subversion (SVN); this GitHub repository is a read-only mirror. Consequently it is not possible to merge this pull request. However parts of it have already been merged manually to the SVN repository.
Thanks for the new tests, this is appreciated! I will try to merge them on SVN tomorrow (this Git repository is only a mirror). Do you confirm that you agree to put this code under Apache 2 license?

Thanks for your response and you're very welcome!
I do not only confirm to put this under the license I've already filled the formal license agreement with the ASF and submitted it to the secretary email address.
You should find it in the corresponding ASF database which I assume to exist and further assume you to have access to.

Furthermore, based on your comment I've re-checked the source provided by me regarding the license header.
Obviously, I've - at least in one case - forgot to add the formal license header.
I am going to re-check the whole code provided by me in this commit and am going to re-submit necessary improvements respectively.

Finally, thanks again for your response!
Based on your response I am going to submit further tests.
Please let me know if you want them to get improved in what way if you have certain demands or generally require improvements regarding the tests provided by me.

Thanks! The Apache secretary should send us a notification soon. I will start the merge in the meantime. It will not happen immediately on trunk; I will export the diff from GitHub, apply on JDK8 branch, edit, commit and it will be merged on trunk later this week. The patch will not be applied exactly as provided, but I will post comments on GitHub about the main editions.

I just added some comments, but they do not need action on your side. I applied the proposed changes on my local copy of the patch (not yet committed). Please let me know if you prefer to process differently.
Committed in https://github.com/apache/sis/commit/65f8cfba0778327af48d8771929db8fe88320181
Committed on https://github.com/apache/sis/commit/1f9c213f81e80393ae61863f9952895fdcddde9c

Okay, just in that minute saw you've already commited the changes you accepted.
Thanks!

Shall I push further changes I consider to be improvements?
Further changes I consider to be improvements general in the SIS project NOT in this pull request.

If you wish that would nice! But I propose that you do the patch against JDK8 branch instead of trunk. Also when doing tests, I suggest the following:

* Focus more on the method contract instead than existing method behavior. For example having `toString()` to throw a `NullPointerException` is not part of method contract.
* Verify if an existing test is already doing what you want to test. Try to identify what is new in the test you are adding. This is not necessarily a new method, but may be the context in which the method is invoked.
* Avoid, if possible, to mix downstream functionalities in a test. For example `ArrayEnvelopeTest` should not use `GeneralEnvelope` or `ImmutableEnvelope`.
* Choose variable names saying what the data are instead than their type. For example `coordinate` instead of `doubleArray`.
Closed because changes have been merged into the base repository.

Thanks. Committed on JDK8 branch together with similar changes in other classes where the same pattern was used. I used `appendStringTo` method name. Since Apache SIS is still on Subversion, I could not merge this patch directly, so it may not be shown as "merged" on GitHub. But this is done there: https://github.com/apache/sis/commit/4f0e3ac11a9ac0415c6b4f60cbb84b030a1f329c
Thanks.

This issue has been closed by ASF-Git synchronization tools as a side effect of the migration from Subversion to Git. The old "JDK8" branch (which was a mirror of Subversion repository) has been replaced by a new "geoapi-4.0" branch. The work done in this issue #8 are still of course valid; we will need to investigate how to port them to the new SIS branch.

Because of SIS migration from Subversion to Git, the history has been rewritten and this pull request can no longer be applied on the JDK8 branch. I suggest reapply the change on a new repository. This can be done as below:

```
wget https://patch-diff.githubusercontent.com/raw/apache/sis/pull/8.diff
```

If there is any other pull request that you need to save, save them now with above command (just change "8" by the pull request number).

Then delete this "sis" repository by going in the "settings" menu, bottom of the page. Make sure that you have saved all your pull requests first. Make sure that you have a local copy of your work.

Re-fork the https://github.com/apache/sis project and execute the following commands:

```
git clone https://github.com/haonguyen123/sis
cd sis
git checkout geoapi-4.0
git checkout -b CSW
patch -p1 < ../8.diff
```

You may have a conflict in `project.properties`. We can ignore it for now:

```
git checkout ide-project/NetBeans/nbproject/project.properties
find . -name "*.orig" -delete
find . -name "*.rej" -delete
git add --all
```

Then verify that everything is okay (in particular make sure that files are in their right locations), then you can commit and push.

yes , I understand

Hello Kelsea

Thanks for this cleaning work! But this pull request seems to contain the addition of two files (`Ex2.2.rtf` and `Ex5.8.circ`), but I do not see changes in Java classes. Could it be that the changes have not been pushed? Can you try to execute "git log" in the directory of your SIS clone and tell us the 3 or 4 first records that you see?

Hi Martin, 

That's strange. I don't know where those files came from. When I executed "git log", here were the records that I saw:

Date:   Mon Aug 6 20:12:57 2018 -0700

    Merge https://github.com/apache/sis
    Merging master branch with my local branch.

commit c0285273453128352190ca5c584181a4d8a987eb

Looking at the commit referenced in the log message, I did not found modifications in the `index/tree` files. Maybe it would be easier to restart from a fresh copy? What about the following steps?

1. Save somewhere the files that you modified in the `storage/sis-storage/src/main/java/org/apache/sis/index/tree/` directory.
2. Delete the `https://github.com/kelseaflores/sis` repository.
3. Go on `https://github.com/apache/sis` and click on the "Fork" button in the upper-right corner.
4. In the popup window, select your account. This will create a new `https://github.com/kelseaflores/sis` repository in replacement of the one we deleted in step 2.
5. Overwrite the files in the `storage/sis-storage/src/main/java/org/apache/sis/index/tree/` directory with the ones that you saved at step 1.
6. Execute `git add -u`, then `mvn install` for verifying that the tests pass, then `git commit` (with a commit message of your choice) and finally `git push`.

I've completed the first 4 steps, but how do I overwrite the files in the storage/sis-storage/src/main/java/org/apache/sis/index/tree/ directory with the ones I saved in step 1? I just want to make sure I'm doing it correctly.

I suggest to use the command line. Ley say that you saved your work in `/home/mydirectory/backup/`. Then from the directory containing the new clone:

```
cd storage/sis-storage/src/main/java/org/apache/sis/index/tree/
cp /home/mydirectory/backup/*.java .
```

The commands may be different on Windows (I think it is `chdir` instead of `cd`, maybe `copy` instead of `cp`).
I've overwritten the files and executed "git add -u", but when I execute "mvn install", the tests fail.
Can you post the error message? Not necessarily the whole Maven output, but at least the lines having the [ERROR] header.

Here are the lines with the [ERROR] header: 

[ERROR] The goal you specified requires a project to execute but there is no POM in this directory (/Users/kelseaflores/Desktop/summer_project/sis/storage/sis-storage/src/main/java/org/apache/sis/index/tree). Please verify you invoked Maven from the correct directory. -> [Help 1]
[ERROR] 
[ERROR] To see the full stack trace of the errors, re-run Maven with the -e switch.
[ERROR] Re-run Maven using the -X switch to enable full debug logging.
[ERROR] 
[ERROR] For more information about the errors and possible solutions, please read the following articles:
[ERROR] [Help 1] http://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/MissingProjectException

The `mvn install` command should be executed from the `/Users/kelseaflores/Desktop/summer_project/sis/` directory. More generally, it needs to be executed from a directory containing a `pom.xml` file (it can be the `storage/sis-storage/` sub-directory if you do not want to build the whole project).

When i ran it from /Users/kelseaflores/Desktop/summer_project/sis/, the tests still fail. Here are the error messages: 

[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-checkstyle-plugin:3.0.0:check (default) on project sis-storage: You have 11 Checkstyle violations. -> [Help 1]
[ERROR] 
[ERROR] To see the full stack trace of the errors, re-run Maven with the -e switch.
[ERROR] Re-run Maven using the -X switch to enable full debug logging.
[ERROR] 
[ERROR] For more information about the errors and possible solutions, please read the following articles:
[ERROR] [Help 1] http://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/MojoFailureException
[ERROR] 
[ERROR] After correcting the problems, you can resume the build with the command
[ERROR]   mvn <goals> -rf :sis-storage

On top of those error messages, you should have a list of files where checkstyle violations occurred. It may be minor things like trailing spaces at end of lines. It may seems exaggerated to make the build fail for such a minor thing as extraneous space at end of lines, but the reason for that is that spaces added or removed at end of line looks invisible in the editor, but are still identified by source versioning system (Git, SVN, â€¦) as a change. So this requirement avoid to have lines falsely flagged as modified when developers commit.

I figured out what the violations were. When I was reformatting the indentations in the files from 2 spaces to 4, Eclipse made the 4 spaces into tabs. I tried changing the formatting preferences in Eclipse so that the tabs are replaced with 4 spaces, but my preference changes are not being applied to the code.
You may try to indent the code by 4 more spaces, then de-indent it. It may work.
The tests are passing now. I went to each file and manually replaced all of the tabs with 4 spaces.
Now that the tests are passing, I've completed all of the steps. I've committed and pushed the code. Do I need to make a new pull request?

You pushed at which URL? The commit that I see at https://github.com/kelseaflores/sis/commit/d55b9b85ba1988748ff18697dba49d8a8ce4b40c seems to be something else. Does `git status` said "nothing to commit (working directory clean)"?

"Git status" says: 
nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)

And I pushed to this URL: https://github.com/kelseaflores/sis

When clicking on the "commit" button, we can see a commit named _"Committing formatting changes - replacing 2 space indentations with 4 space indentations"_. But when clicking on that commit, what we see (the link posted in my previous comment) seems another work.

What are the untracked files listed by Git? And what is the output of `git log`? (only the 2 or 3 first records).

All of the untracked files were all of the other files and directories in my Desktop directory. 

And the output of "git log" is:

It is strange that Git see files of your Desktop directory. Looking at the commits reported by `git log`, I do not see any modification in `sis-storage/â€¦/index/`. I do not see modifications on https://github.com/kelseaflores/sis/tree/master/storage/sis-storage/src/main/java/org/apache/sis/index/tree neither.

Maybe we should try again in another way. From the command line:

```
cd <any sub-directory. Make sure you are in an empty sub-directory>
git clone https://github.com/apache/sis
cd sis
git push --force https://github.com/kelseaflores/sis
```

Note: this will discard your commits, but those commits seem accidental anyway. The intent is to verify that those steps work before to move to next step.
Okay, just completed those steps.

Now I suggest to open the `storage/sis-storage/src/main/java/org/apache/sis/index/tree` folder and copy there the classes that you modified. After the copy, the following command should give a list of modified Java files:

```
git status
```
Okay I've copied all of the modified files, and "git status" gives a list of those files.

Thanks. Then we can try:

```
git add -u
git commit -m "<the message>"
git push
```

After those command have been executed, we should see the modified files [in your repository](https://github.com/kelseaflores/sis/tree/master/storage/sis-storage/src/main/java/org/apache/sis/index/tree). At that point we can try a new merge request again.

When I executed "git push" it said: 
remote: Permission to apache/sis.git denied to kelseaflores.
fatal: unable to access 'https://github.com/apache/sis/': The requested URL returned error: 403

So I executed "git push https://github.com/kelseaflores/sis" and it said: 
Everything up-to-date

Does that mean my modified files were correctly pushed to GitHub?
I still do not see the file on GitHub. What does `git branch` said? Then `git status`?

"git branch" is saying: * master

"git status" is saying: 
Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)

	QuadTree.java
	QuadTreeData.java
	QuadTreeNode.java
	QuadTreeWriter.java

nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
In which directory are those files? Are they in the root directory (I mean, do you see `LICENSE` and `NOTICE` files in the same directory than `QuadTree.java`, `QuadTreeNode.java`, _etc._)?
Yes, I see LICENSE and NOTICE files in the same directory. Are the files in the wrong directory?

Yes, the files need to be moved. You can do that with the following command:

```
mv *.java storage/sis-storage/src/main/java/org/apache/sis/index/tree/
```

Then ```git status``` should list those files as _modified_ files (as opposed to untracked files). This is because we replaced existing files (which were already tracked) by the new ones. You can then execute ```git add -u```, then ```git status``` again. The files should now be listed as files staged for commit. Before to commit, I suggest to run ```mvn install``` for making sure that tests pass. Then ```git commit``` and ```git push``` to your repository as you did before.
The tests passed and I was able to push my code to GitHub!
Cool! I can see your work on https://github.com/kelseaflores/sis/tree/master/storage/sis-storage/src/main/java/org/apache/sis/index/tree :) Then you can close this pull request and create a new one.
Doing that now. Thank you so much for helping me through that!
Merged, thanks! I have also cherry-picked this commit to the `geoapi-4.0` branch, which is the current development branch.

You are welcome, thanks for your contribution!
(for the record: this merge request is superseded by #10).

This pull request is actually empty. It looks big because it contains numerous commits from a development branch to be merge to master, but it does not contains any commit done outside that development branch. Do you have a link to your source code repository where you committed the SIS-440 fix, so we can take a look at what happened?
JIRA task at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SIS-452

Alternatively, a possible approach could be to accept those features as features without geometry. In this case, the fix could be to modify lines 816- 858 for skipping geometry construction, and make sure that the `FeatureType` has no geometry property.

A fix attempt has been done in commit c9abccdfef31e050d214a5ba70c82ffe86c77020 but can not be verified without the test file. The committed fix creates features without geometry (which is legal) instead of discarding the whole feature set.

A different approach has been implemented in commit 844534c6eb7d7504d634fda1e14b70bc44a905b3. Instead of catching exceptions in `DataStoreRegistry`, we continue to let each `DataStoreProvider` decide if an exception is recoverable or fatal. But if a `DataStoreProvider` decides to propagate an exception, a new `CanNotProbeException` allows to specify in which provider the error occurred. Callers can catch this exception and exclude the provider from next probe operations.

We do not catch exception in `DataStoreRegistry` because not all exceptions are recoverable. For example an `IOException` caused by a damaged file is not the fault of any particular provider, and should cause the probe operation to stop for all providers. Whether an exception is recoverable or not is a decision left to each `DataStoreProvider`.

As an illustration of this policy, above commit contains a change in `NetcdfStoreProvider` where all `IOException` are considered recoverable. This is okay because the change is applied in a context where the stream is opened by the UCAR library from a file path specified as a `String`. The data source is a string or a `Path` or a `URL`, etc. There is no damaged `InputStream` left behind.

The documentation improvement has been merged (with editions) in Apache SIS code base. The heuristic rules have been replaced by an extension mechanism allowing users to specify their own heuristic rules. The rules that were implemented in this merge request have been ported to https://github.com/Geomatys/geotoolkit/commit/55d609cea682963bc4479955d40e1034de851439 as a proof of work.
@desruisseaux  I still cannot assign it to you. I'd like your review please.

OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.
The upgrade for this release has been done in commit 1a2bc02b6fc6067d96e15c5302fc01dc805f1919.

The fix, which adds intermediate points during the "envelope to JTS" conversion, is modified in two ways:

* Instead of adding mid-points, add points on the edges of axis ranges (e.g. 180Â°E or 180Â°W).
* Disabled for now, because generally not needed after SIS-547 and SIS-486 new fixes.

We need to revisit what could be a public API for enabling the insertion of additional points on demand.
@dependabot rebase
Looks like org.hsqldb:hsqldb is up-to-date now, so this is no longer needed.
@dependabot rebase
Looks like org.postgresql:postgresql is up-to-date now, so this is no longer needed.

Will apply this pull request with some amendments. This pull request changes the `TIMESTAMP_WITH_TIMEZONE` mapping from `java.time.OffsetDateTime` to `java.time.Instant`. I propose to keep the previous `OffsetDataTime`. Some searches on internet suggest that this mapping is part of JDBC 4.2 specification:

* [JDBC Maintenance Release 4.2](https://jcp.org/aboutJava/communityprocess/maintenance/jsr221/JDBC4.2MR-January2014.pdf)
* [Using Java 8 Date and Time classes in PostgreSQL](https://jdbc.postgresql.org/documentation/query/#using-java-8-date-and-time-classes)
* [Mapping between PostgreSQL and Java date/time types](https://tada.github.io/pljava/use/datetime.html)

Additional commits added after the merge for this tasks:

* 4984b31e9c617a63b3a5bdf9a31f539064dea6c3 â€” Replace reflection by `ServiceLoader` uses in the `OptionalDependency` class.
* 6812aa0843fd381e28f9e1b6d288fadf40d29cde â€” Give public access to JAXB adapters in internal API.
* 659e00a4383001144490d928f32bd5aa3d03ba59 â€” All tests shall open resource files from the module containing the resources.
* 25eb197481decb91c8a4dadf770c4bcf0cb7c693 â€” Relax a check from `assertSame(â€¦) to `assertEquals(â€¦)` for test that may depend on execution order.
* 0cd54bd9de9f1d53f510324a753c1d16dfc498b4 â€” `ResourceInternationalString` needs to let subclasses invoke `ResourceBundle.getBundle(â€¦)` themselves.
* bb45c5eb60ea8f67484f348eb6a97fbf2c39926e â€” Avoid using `ServiceLoader` directly in the test, because it will not run in a JPMS context.
* 18e2964bf2afd0b03a178b8973bd0d545e013a3c â€” `ScriptRunner.run(â€¦)` shall receive an `InputStream` supplied by the caller.
* c25bbe6e9c6114913a9bfa64bc57dbe589b6699f â€” Ensure that `InputStream` marks are supported. This is not always the case in a JPMS context.
* 3c96c2597cfe15ec593c3dd3f7c0b26c9ae2f818 â€” Opens two more classes to reflection by JAXB in JPMS context.
* f5390fda93ec9cac713924a1b83d8037ad0e4caf â€” Upgrade JavaEE (now JakartaEE) and OSGi dependencies.
* 7c87ae6e3265f7a5a787164f50a505c108c5906d â€” Avoid dependency toward `org.apache.sis.test` in modules that are still in incubating phase.
@dependabot rebase
Looks like com.h2database:h2 is up-to-date now, so this is no longer needed.

Could this be done incrementally in two (or more) PRs? Something like:

1. Migrate from Maven to Gradle (no JPMS) 
2. Support JPMS (add `module-info.java`)

Or maybe each step you listed is a separate PR? I'm wondering if it will reduce the impacted surface area making it easier to track what's changed (instead of reviewing the large number of files here).

We could split in separated merge requests, but the migration from Maven to Gradle is very different depending on whether it is done before or after restructuring from _Package Hierarchy_ to _Module Source Hierarchy_. If we migrate to Gradle before, it would be like doing the migration twice given the amount of changes needed in Gradle scripts and plugins (`buildSrc`) after restructuring to Module Source Hierarchy.

Currently the separation is done in commits as below. Those commits are in dependency order, and each of them could be taken as a merge request on its own (git "squash" and "rebase" were done extensively).

1. Cleaning work
    * Remove the NetBeans Ant project
    * Remove test JAR files. Consequently tests cannot be executed anymore (temporarily)
2. Partial JPMS
    * Add `module-info.java`. Project can still be executed with Maven, but not tested.
3. Restructuring from Package Hierarchy to Module Source Hierarchy
    * Remove all Maven project files (because they don't work at all with Module Source Hierarchy)
    * Move all Java source files to their new location with no change in any code.
    * Post move cleanup (code changes caused by restructuring are separated in this commit).
4. Migrage from Maven to Gradle.
    * Add Gradle build scripts, adapted to Module Source Hierarchy.
    * Documentation updates (mostly editions in Javadoc).

As seen above, the commits are in 4 groups which could be separated in 4 merge requests. The reason why they are proposed in a single merge request is because the project is temporarily unbuildable and/or untestable during some intermediate steps. The project is back to buildable and testable state only after the last commit (ignoring the documentation updates).

So would it still be better to split in 2 or more merge requests anyway?

This is a great explanation. My personal opinion and preference is to have
each commit as a separate PR just to make it easier to follow and track the
changes. Especially as time passes it's kind of nice to go back and see
smaller PRs. I think if the build doesn't pass it's okay? Especially since
main is an unstable snapshot anyway? Just my $0.02.

Actually splitting this big pull request (PR) seems difficult because the smaller PRs would not be independent. The second PR would need to either wait for the merge of the first PR before to be created (in which case peoples [voting](https://lists.apache.org/thread/w7llc33nglxp0jvmmq186wm52k2wwcd5) cannot see the full picture), or to contain the first PR which would result in the same thing than this PRâ€¦

I presume that the goal is to have diffs easier to read. Bellow are the diffs over the ranges of commits for the two main tasks. They show what smaller pull requests would contain:

* [Adding `module-info.java` and removing Maven `pom.xml` files](https://github.com/apache/sis/compare/6e7bc316e92d141faa77e393d09657a3fc6b0612..0d5a57f562fab7c6e825ad03a8f0c3459ffcb56d)
* [Adding Gradle scripts and migrating Maven POJO to Gradle plugin](https://github.com/apache/sis/compare/b8eeb4789171cdef2e782b684fe52c178947079e..70ccdd51e5398ed5727795ae03522b7c98a284fe)

What if you switched the order? Don't enable JPMS (e.g., add `module-info.java`) until the very last step (e.g., step 4).

For example,

1. Rote refactor the classes to a "module hierarchy" (e.g., no split packages so JPMS will be happy in the end)
2. Cleaning Work
3. Migrate from Maven to Gradle
4. Enable JPMS.

The rote refactor shouldn't break any builds? Maybe the cleaning work does because you're removing ANT? In which case you could merge 2 and 3? Remove ANT while migrating from Maven to Gradle. Lastly, JPMS doesn't have to be enabled until gradle build passes. By then all of your classes should be in distinct packages so adding the `module-info.java` files shouldn't do anything other than enable the module system. 

PS. Just take my thoughts as ideas for traceability. I'm not actually doing any of the work and I know the time requirement can be burdensome so I'd happily +1 as is if this would be a crazy amount of redo work.

The refactoring that we could do without breaking the build were already done. It was the topic of #34. When I was working on modularisation, I was preparing those two merge requests simultaneously with lot of "git rebase" and squashes. This merge request contains commits that couldn't be moved to the "pre-migration" phase.

The reason why JPMS had to be done before Gradle migration is because the _Module Source Hierarchy_ is not just about resolving package name clashes. It is a more disruptive feature, supported by standard Java tools since Java 9 but not well known, maybe because neither Gradle or Maven supports it (but Gradle flexibility makes possible to get it working anyway). Module Source Hierarchy is explained briefly in the [Directory Hierarchies](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/20/docs/specs/man/javac.html#directory-hierarchies) section of Oracle's documentation. I tried to explain more in section 1 of [Java Module Source Hierarchy in a Gradle sub-project](https://geomatys.github.io/draft/Modularization.html) page. Finally I opened issue https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/25974 for better support of this feature. It is the application of Module Source Hierarchy, not the addition of `module-info.java` files, which implies a very different way to build the Gradle scripts. So JPMS cannot be moved after Gradle migration, because the migration work is too different depending if done before or after Module Source Hierarchy.
This task is recorded in JIRA issue https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SIS-582.

Since #37 the build system is no longer Maven (it is now Gradle), so this pull request can not be merged anymore. However the `Built-On` attribute fixed by this pull request is no longer added to the `META-INF/MANIFEST.MF` file. The content of that file is now like below (no more builder-dependent information):

```
Manifest-Version: 1.0
Specification-Title: GeoAPI
Specification-Vendor: Open Geospatial Consortium
Specification-Version: 3.0.2
Implementation-Title: Apache Spatial Information System (SIS)
Implementation-Vendor: The Apache Software Foundation
Implementation-Version: 1.4-SNAPSHOT
Main-Class: org.apache.sis.gui.DataViewer
```
